children.subject: I wouldn't say it's not EE, it's just not what you think of when you first think of EE (i.e. circuits)

history.content:
Why do people think that EE implies circuits? EE is a very big tent intellectually (look at the various societies and journals of the IEEE), and has been for many many decades. Fields grow organically following intellectual threads and patterns. It doesn't necessarily have to make any sense to an outsider. Information theory, control theory, signal processing, continuous optimization, and basically anything that leans heavy into linear algebra and probability have traditionally been a part of EE. That's the kind of thing that was "EE theory" as distinct from the more combinatorial and propositional-logic-based perspectives of what was traditionally considered "CS theory." 

Times have changed from even two decades ago and in a way, everything is more and more traditional EE-style now even in domains that used to be more combinatorial. At the same time, CS is also becoming more of a big tent. But since Berkeley is an EECS department --- one big tent with lots of internal diversity --- there's not really much reason to think about this except as interesting intellectual and cultural history. Barely on par with questions like "why do airplanes fly but submarines don't swim?" Maybe interesting as linguistics, but has nothing really substantive to do with making airplanes or submarines.
